name:
The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Buzsaki and Dr. Marder. Dr. Buzsaki's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Marder studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The two are having a public academic panel discussion about the function of the higher-order-cortex.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. B: 'What do you think is the primary purpose of the association areas in the mouse cortex?'
Dr. M:'I think they primarily maintain synchronous firing patterns'.'

Dr. B:'Why? What is synchronizing them all over the cortex? What role can they play? Can you give me an example about a few patterns that a very particular set of those areas might synchronize, or maintain in the absence of visual input from the retina?'
Dr. M: 'When you think of a network, like a neuron circuit, what are  the 'final goals' of a neuron circuit? What is its purpose?'
Dr. B:"Well, I don't know if there are 'final goals', but we want to figure it out.'
Dr. M:'Well, maybe the brain as an information archive.'
Dr. B:'What do you think it would be.'

Dr. M:'Well, so let me tell you the purpose of our work. For many years we were working on a model of the brain that was based on the properties of the pyloric neurons in the PD (Pyloric Dilator) and LP (Lateral Pyloric) cells of the STG in the pyloric circuit. And we were trying to see if we could get the different circuits of neurons, neurons that are involved in brain processes, like emotion, to come in synchrony with each other. We didn't think that was possible. But we thought that we would be able to understand the brain by doing the measurements, getting single neurons, working with multiple neurons, that you've done so elegantly in your experiments.'

Dr. B:'So if your primary goal is to fire in synchrony, then your neurons at the right times, at the right rates, then they are the right neurons in the right layer and they are the right types of connections, then the goal is achieved, because these connections are created and maintained by a limited number of neurons. So here is  a simple circuit, and it is the circuit that is connected to a motor neuron and the motor neuron's primary goal is to exert an action.  Now, this is simply a very simple circuit. It has only a motor neuron. It does not have any intermediate or higher-order-layer neurons, and so it requires that the activity of the interneurons be maintained synchronously and they are in the right time window. But here is  a more complicated circuit, where the two main goals of the lower-order-layer and the higher-order neurons and  the inhibitory interneurons are maintained synchronously.'
Dr. M:'The association areas?'

Dr. B:'Yes. Such as the visual cortex for the vision, the somatosensory cortex for the somatosensa-tion, the motor cortex for motor or the like in mammals. Why are these areas there? My answer is, that without them, there would be a lack of neuronal connectivity in the brain, because to form a neural system, the brain needs at least four to five connections in any system. And all connections, including the brain connections, are based on the connection of the nerves. The connection of the nerves is based on the activity of the spinal cord, which is a giant mass of uncoordinated neurons. But how would uncoordinated neurons connect to each other?'
Dr. M: We have learned over the last decades, that the connectivity of the brain depends very much on the kind of activity, or the oscillations the brain is trying to serve.'
Dr. M:'Association area.'
Dr. M: 'These are the association areas.'

Dr. B:'The association areas are primary and most important. If you ever look through a microscope in the brain, you will be amazed about the complexity of the neuron types. The cell type that is closest to the general rule is the layer 6 neuron, which can be called pyramidal neuron in the frontal cortex of the mouse. Those neurons are so simple that they have five branches. At the base of each ramification, the bouton is packed with excitatory postsynaptic chemical receptors, which allows my neighbors to talk to me. In my lab, I have trained a lot of students what is a layer 6 pyramidal cell. Our students are good at these simple-cell-type tasks. Many of them, like myself, are interested in more complex neuronal functions. But there are very big problems. For example, how should they deal with these neurons and how would they know them?'
Dr. M:'A purpose?'

Dr. B:'There must be a purpose. If you look, they have a lot of independent neurons that control the movements of the heart. And you know there must be some functionality over there because, you know, you wouldn't have independent neurons for that.'
Dr. M:'Yeah this will be fine,' then we can go back out into the room where there are like all these people.'
Dr. M:Well yeah, so you're just talking about the synaptic transmission?'

Dr. B:'Yeah, well, synaptic transmission?that is a big term that is actually a technical thing. And it refers to the procedure by which information, in the case of the brain, gets packaged into electrical signals and sent off to its recipient neurons.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'
Dr. B:'So the synaptic transmission is part of the transmission of information. You're sending electrical signals, you're giving, there must be some meaning there.'

Dr. B:'This is a question that, I think, we can answer. But we can also answer it differently. What is the primary function of the mouse cortex? Not what they do, not how they interact with the environment, but a purpose. In a sense, the primary goal of the mouse cortex would be to achieve a long-lasting effect of some sort: long effects of long-lasting effects. And this is why we want to know what the mechanisms are that these areas do. So whether it's the long-lasting effects, or the long effects of the long-lasting-effects, it doesn't really matter. And it's the same thing because the effects that are so long-lasting is so long lasting, that there is only one thing that has longer consequences: the effect that comes with the other way. Which is why from the very small and simple brain or a little network is that the brain, and the effects that we can achieve are so extraordinary.'
Dr. M:'The association areas? They're part of the sensory circuit.'

Dr. B:'So is the cortex. Do we have evidence that mice lack these areas? Because of their similarity to in humans, if we go back into the evolution of the mouse brain, does the cortex need these association areas? What you guys are interested in is how the evolution of the cortex proceeds.'

Dr. M: 'No. We're not interested in how the evolution of cortex proceeds, because we know that it does. That's really boring, but it's very clear. We're interested in how the association areas evolve, because it remains a mystery why there are as many as there are, and why we have so many of them. Do we know what we're missing? Are there something else in the brain that functions like these, or do we use some other term? We have a lot of term as we have them in the mouse cortex. Do any of these terms, or new ones come from your perspective, or do we need to invent a new vocabulary?'

Dr. B:'No, but you have two areas that do. One of them is the associational part of the cortex, but we have to think about them differently. One of the functions of that area is to keep the brain together so you can concentrate on your problems with your friends or study. The other one is the associational area keeps the mind open and prevents us from thinking about specific things that we couldn't go to sleep for.'

Dr. B:'I'm talking about the associational areas in the brain. They're in the higher order regions and don't have traditional function. Are they related to the primary sensory circuits from the point of view of function? Or how should they be approached in a research-science from the point of function? I realize we can't answer this question for all of the reasons Dr. Vida gives below, but if we're discussing how to answer this question from the perspective of brain function, there is a particular point of view that we can bring to it and I'd like to get your, uh, views as a researcher, uh, in this area of function.'

Dr. B:'They are part of circuit generation?' So, all the neurons that become part of circuits or circuits in the mouse cortex actually have dual identities? So, for example, each neuron is also contributing to the generation of the particular output function of the circuit that they are contributing? So, if you study a given circuit, you can determine which neurons are contributing via which input-output connections. Is this true in humans too? The brain is so compartmentalized that it may be hard to determine what a given neuron is doing when you're studying, for example, the visual cortex, and its neurons are spread throughout the brain. Maybe each neuron projects to several different neurons. So, how do you look at a single neuron, and say "the neuron is doing this in the cortex"?'

Dr. M:'Maybe all the neurons have multiple roles. Maybe neurons have multiple roles just like they do in the networks that they're part of... you know, maybe neurons also express multiple receptors...they express two receptors for example... they express, as a neuron I guess, multiple receptors...but maybe because then you can have different kinds of different circuit patterns...because you can have, you can have neurons with these multiple receptors activated, as would happen to do in the network. But then it can make it possible for neurons to play different roles.'

Dr. B:'One possibility would be that it is the way the brain is organized such that there are different inputs for a given type of function but that a given neuron can express one receptor and one receptors different role or one function. A simple example might be a neuron that expresses a particular class of receptors...so it binds to serotonin receptors, which are responsible for this type of function that the neuron is going to perform. So the neuron in essence becomes a conduit for a particular function that would be related to a particular kind of function.'
Dr. M:'Association areas?'

Dr. M:"We know that the cortex is not 'wired' that way, so that's a first thing. The second thing is the primary input is the movement of skeletal muscles, which are not connected to sensory input at all. Thus, there could be nothing more useful for the cerebral cortex than motor-driven activity. If the cortex was not driven by the skeletal system and muscles in these ways, it doesn't even have a proper job.'

Dr. B:'If you're talking about the somatosensory cortex, I'm not seeing much in it. I'm not seeing how that cortex can do anything useful. No motor command, which is what would make the cortex useful, would have anything to do with that. The association areas do receive peripheral information, but it's the information which is supplied by the skeletal system. And these regions actually, are the motor areas on top there, where there are movement related neurons. This explains why a lot of them respond to movement. Of course motor activity can have nothing to do with the information the cortex receives from the skeletal system and the environment.'
Dr. M:(Pounds a fist into the palm of her hand) 'But, it has a perfectly defined job to perform.'

Dr. B:'Well, I'm not understanding that. And I'm asking how. I'm asking you, what does it do that makes it useful? Can it detect some kind of pattern which would be useful to the cerebral cortex? What would be a useful pattern? We can go on and on about this, but there has to be something that the neocortex-based information processing system can do, which makes it useful for the brain at the molecular level. And the answer in my view is that it just, does nothing. Does it? Is it a motor command? Or is it part of an associative process?'

Dr. M:'It's unclear. I think this is a very complicated question because the way that networks get shaped by activity is not well understood by either of us. My first observation is that if you put a mouse with a group of mice and let it live, the activity in its brain changes because the animal has to respond to its own body. As a mouse starts with a basal level of activity, like it gets to wake up in the light or it gets frightened by some noise, one or two or three or four of these things, this animal might spend all day running around and looking for small targets and chewing the lumps off of sticks for no significant purpose. Once it starts having to deal with itself, then you start getting more and more of this kind of activity as the animal gets used to controlling its own movement in the brain. This may or may not lead the animal to begin to realize that it has purposeful abilities beyond being a small mouse living in some hole. It may not.'

Dr. B:'How does the brain respond to this? Does the brain have to do some work to figure out that this animal is being used to learn those behaviors, or does the brain already do that work by finding activity in the frontal lobe or lateral geniculate, and does that activity bring about certain changes in the brain? And then, from that, does this animal become able to choose behaviors that would require those structures to change or does the brain just take it to the next level? And if they ever end up doing those behaviors and learning those things, can they have a longer memory of those things? How does the brain do that? Is there a special circuit in the brain that's dedicated to this, or is that just another layer of changes in the brain?'

Dr. M:'Oh, it looks like there's two modes to control the pylorus rhythm. One mode is controlled by the pacemaker group in the pylorus circuit. On these two other sides there are also the members of that circuit that send their axons along the motor nerves and produce the rhythmic movement of the pylorus.'
Dr. M: 'Oh yes. We think it controls the rhythms of both sides.'

Dr. M:'I think it's more than you think. It's important that the interaction between the different neurons be maintained at all times. But if that's the primary function of the association area, I'd say it's very important, because otherwise you'd lose the interaction that's vital for communication, and I think you might lose some of the regulation of the network.'
Dr. B:'So it can allow you to modulate each other?'

Dr. B:"I don't think we've learned whether the activation itself in the brain is a useful thing to try to understand, by itself. So we have this idea that the cortical association neurons are important for interactions between neurons, and there are a lot of other factors that may be important as well. So I'm a little bit hesitant to say whether you get a secondary benefit from their activation by itself, because there are other features of cortical neurons that are related to their role in modulation.'
Dr. M:'But it's a little bit the same with the hippocampal neurons. The way they fire. That's important for their input into the neuromodulatory system.'
Dr. B:"Yes, that's right. That also has an expression domain as well as a functional expression domain, and I think that's important to consider.'
Dr. M:'What do you think?'
Dr. B:'What do you say? What is your answer?'
Dr. M:'You know, I think you've been there twice, I've been there only once, but, okay, the primary, like, the very primary thing is to allow the sensory inputs to come.'

Dr. B:'It's a tough question because many are brain-wide and they could just be a homolog of some sensory part. So it is difficult to guess without knowing the particular purpose that is being served, and so it's actually a hard problem to answer.'

Dr. M: 'Now, I know where that's coming from. This would be a huge disservice to your work because you've done so much for me over the decades, and now when I'm talking to you about a tough problem, your brain pops into your mind and all of a sudden it comes up with a perfectly detailed answer, but not before I've asked the question. It's the perfect response.'

Dr. B:'So what was my answer last time when you asked the exact same question about the hippocampus? And your answer, of course, is that it is the memory consolidation and the memory buffer and the association areas is the primary purpose for all of its connections.'
Dr. M:'The memory buffer I don't think we ever used this before.'
Dr. B:'What do you need to happen?'
Dr. M: What do you think is?'

Dr. B:'Well, my question is what is the primary function of the association areas? I am not referring to the frontal eye field or frontal eye field area but the lateral intraparietal area, but what is the purpose? I'm not referring to those areas as their function or what have they done. What do you suggest? What is the primary function that such area serves? Can you give me examples?'
Dr. B:'What do we know about these areas?'
Dr. B:'I think one of the primary function is to regulate synaptic transmission.'
Dr. M:'So maybe to regulate synaptic transmission in the mouse and the  C. elegans  neuron?'

Dr. B:'Is the primary purpose of them to help with speech and hearing, or is the primary purpose that I can think of for it to use brain circuits to process information? I can think of so many scenarios, but that's not the thing as long as your first answer is that their primary purpose is to help with hearing and speech, that would be good. What else could a mouse cortex do? I have no idea.'
Dr. M:'I have no idea.'

Dr. B:"Well I guess it also allows mice to move. I mean there are very few times when, when we see a mouse, they're walking, they're moving, and they're trying to run away from something. But for those moments when they're walking they're taking the opportunity to collect information, they're trying to sniff, their whiskers are moving, and those movement sensors are all collecting and being able to tell them about objects around them; if you're a mouse you learn to do that, you learn to use those information-gathering areas. But that's not the primary goal. Of course the primary goal is not to be a mouse, because then your stomach would be full of worms, right?'

Dr. M:'I think it is to aggregate. The association areas, in and of itself, are not functionally useful in any way; all the neurons that are present there are already present in the single ganglion. The only role for them in a larger circuit is if there are neurons that you want to aggregate, to have several pathways to be able to aggregate.'
Dr. B:'And do you think that they influence circuit function or circuit reconfiguration, or do they just kind of get to aggregate and do some stuff?'

Dr. M: 'So it is kind of a bit of both. Some of the information has to be aggregated. And I think their primary function is to aggregate, to aggregate that information into larger bundles, because as soon as a nervous system has multiple neuromodulators and neurons and neuromodulators interacting the neurons have their own synaptic connections, and their own interaction patterns, and each neuron will do a different thing.'

Dr. M:'Well, there is no primary purpose. I think it's to allow for integration, as well as segregation from the other cell types. They allow for integration to other neurons, allowing them to have feedback control. Well, one of the functions of the association areas on in the mouse cortex is to provide for electrical coupling between neurons. So, all of the cortical neurons are electrically coupled to each other through an extensive network of the associated ganglia, through the stomatogastric nerve. So, there is electrical coupling between all of these nervous systems. So, you're giving me electrical coupling, so to allow electrical conduction to take place from cell to cell in a network, and back up to the brain. So, and these are two different mechanisms, that are different types of electrical coupling, and may serve slightly different purposes in the network in some aspects. The question really is: what is the primary purpose for the electrical coupling in the cortex of a mammal like the mouse?'

Dr. B:'Now, you're a very interesting question. So there's a very broad definition of what electrical coupling is, which is when an electrically chargeable medium separates two charged mediums, by transferring the charge. So, there are various, but mainly two types of electrophysiological coupling of electrically charged ions or molecules, of a charged molecule, and a charged medium. And that is electroneutrality. And that is the fundamental mechanism of electrical coupling. So when we go back to the question of the primary motivation? The primary motivation for this electric coupling is to allow for electrical communication with a charged group of electrically charged molecules. Not electrically charged molecules, but electrically charged molecules between those electrically charged molecules to have electromagnetic communication. Again. So, what is our motivation? What is the primary goal that we're looking to achieve? We have a variety of different, electrical connections between neurons and glial cells in the brain.'
Dr. M:'Or it could be to provide ionic conductance, synaptic connections?'
Dr. M:'Oh, okay.'
Dr. M:'So, electrical coupling is more fundamental than synaptic, obviously.'

Dr. M:'There are likely to be several functions... In the case of the association areas of the mouse cortex, it is likely that the primary purpose of those structures would be to ensure that, whenever two or more sensory information-storing neurons are active together, they are coordinated. I am very worried that when different neurons fire in response to sensory input, as we are seeing in this sort of simultaneous firing of the two sensory networks, the neurons which should be coordinating will not and thus will be lost sight of.'
Dr. B:'I see, so what is the secondary function?'
Dr. M:'I suppose the brain will eventually solve this problem, but I find it very difficult, because what we are looking for is what makes behavior change...'
Dr. M:'They provide a bridge between sensory and motor circuits.'
Dr. B:'Exactly?'
Dr. M:'And some people want to be able to take actions by themselves.'
Dr. M: 'But there's also a notion that a bridge between sensory circuit and motor circuit is important—that a bridge is important.'

Dr. B:-Exactly—and in the mouse, the association areas, which are two small patches, are one of many of many of these little bridges that we know exists. That would mean that these associations are necessary for our basic function then?' That the mouse cannot take actions by itself without the associative areas?'
Dr. M:-Absolutely.'

Dr. M:'So, you take, for example, this, this, this network, which is the primary sensory neuron, the pacemaker of the brain, the core of all the sensory neurons in a small network. When a stimulus comes in through a single sensory or motor neuron, it has nowhere to go, because it has sensory circuits and motor circuits. If you take this network itself, if a stimulus comes through a neuropil, a small aperture that's in the head between the fore- and the central-fornixes, through the pyloric dilator nerve that goes through the lateral ventrical, you can open it up and you can look into the posterior ventrial nerve, which opens up to the association areas where the small motor networks and the small sensory networks are actually in direct contact with each other. The association area is filled with nerves that branch into tiny processes and make direct contact with neurons in the individual networks.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of these processes?'

Dr. M:'Yes. So those processes are actually very important for the transfer of electrical and chemical excitation in the small networks, and from a peripheral, extralemnal nerve, as an exciting stimulus, these are excitable membranes and they respond to electrically-excitable neurons, so those neurons themselves send electrical excitation as a secondary action and that excitation then travels on these synaptic pathways through the peripheral system.'

Dr. B:'Okay. The reason why these inhibitory connections are so critical is, is, is because that's where the control, the inhibition, comes in. Now you can see it a little differently. So, if you have two groups of neurons, A and B, and if the excitation travels across that association area, and in response to A, that neuron that goes on to B neurons is inhibited, and because it's an inhibitory, this is a mechanism to provide control and inhibition and stability. Now again, it is a secondary action.'

Dr. B:"So, actually, so one of the reasons your answer is, is one of the reasons the pacemaker function is so important is because it's, it's just providing a local site for an excitation from the periphery to travel to the central-firing neurons.'

Dr. B:'But, but even in the absence of sensory perturbations, what could be done with this network? What changes would be happening? What kind of alterations would occur? What would an experiment look like? How would we see them? How would we determine them? How should we be looking at the circuit itself?'
Dr. B:'How can I ask a question from you that you can respond to effectively? It must be about a topic that you find interesting and challenging.'
Dr. M:' I don't know. I'd like to know what the primary purposes that the higher cortical structures serve'.'

Dr. B:' Okay. So here's my take. What higher-order functions are critical or important and are relevant to humans is that they have evolved. So I think there is a purpose of evolution of the cortex that has something to do with functions. So for example, we have this problem to solve, this problem of understanding perception. Perception in humans has changed and evolved over time. In fact, a couple of years ago we looked at a study and we found that humans of different races show differences in perception. So for example African-Americans tend to be better at perception than the other races. Whites and Americans. So we were interested in seeing whether maybe the same thing is happening in a laboratory monkey. So we tested whether monkeys in the laboratory could perceive and behave appropriately as their species did in their normal environments. We found they couldn't.'
Dr. M:' Oh, really?'
Dr. M: 'Yes.'
Dr. B:: It's huge.'

Dr. M:'The association areas are supposed to be the sites of activity, and that's what they're used for. Right'? We have identified activity-dependent genes, and people think that the genes that are regulated during development must be genes involved in controlling what activity is going to happen in the adult. And that's not correct at all. Because the association areas are already active, that is the activity-dependent genes that are regulated in these association areas, must be involved in activity of the mouse.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think it depends on the preparation. Some mice have one or two small areas -you know, I think the largest one is, like, a little island and then it's smaller than that island in both direction. So that's it. But if you use, you know, if you create these mice with the single-cell-type neuron, then you are essentially generating these network models with a one kind of neuron. And it's really hard to do that, you know because then you have all the complexities of the networks that you want from them, and you also have your single-cell-neuron properties. So in some cases it's simpler to have one or two, you know, maybe three neuron types. So that's the case that I know is, like, simpler in that sense.'
Dr. B:'Is there a goal? Do we know what we want in the future? Or is it just a goal in addition to the science that we are working on?'

Dr. M:'I think that is one of the big issues. It's clear in my mind that when you want to do a cell type experiment, you want to understand something, you know. I have three cell types in my mind for example. So, it's clear. And I think in general, yeah, I think we want to understand how synaptic strengths change or some other properties that may occur in a cell and at how a cell is put together. I think that is one example of when I thought it was clear that I had wanted to understand the mechanisms of synapse reversal potentials and the fact that you can change or change a synaptic connection of a synapse or a synaptic conductance in a neuron to a different direction. Yeah, so that's one thing that really, it wasn't clear. That is, at that point in time, did you know, this wasn't done. So that was the next direction.'

Dr. B:'So, how is it then clear how you would actually find what you would be looking for after several years? Because the longer this goes on, the larger is the problem of the next big thing that we have to do in the brain. It doesn't seem to have an end.'
Dr. B:'So, you know, what are the advantages of that? And what are the disadvantages of that?'

Dr. M:'What do you consider as an advantage? I mean I think like how can we do this using smaller numbers of cells, like, you know, as you said initially you had two neurons and the other four were peripheral cells, so how can we build neurons from cells that are different? Like how are we going to do this by starting with five cells and then growing it?'
Dr. B:] 'You know, that's the problem. Can you start with five neurons and grow it? How are we going to grow an army of neurons?'
Dr. M: 'But we still have this problem of how does the network grow?'

Dr. B:'Well, and what is growth? You know, what is the growth? So you may say that it's growth in terms of network size. You may say that it is expansion in the number of cells that a single mouse can have and so forth. There are many other ways, just like you said the number of branches and so the number of things goes on forever. What I'm asking you is what's the strategy? What is your strategy for how this network is going to grow and expand?'
Dr. M:'Um, well it sounds like a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem.'

Dr. M: 'So then there's another concern that maybe, you know, this is a problem as you say in the other part of your lecture that, you know, is it a problem to start with, so how are you going to get the connectivity to grow? Because, you know, in other models the mice, the spiny lobsters, which are native to North Atlantic Ocean in which there are no known neurons, the neurons had been cultured and they are all distinct, they all come from a different type of cells. So they all have distinct properties. But in developing those types of models you have to start with neurons that maybe aren't genetically distinct. And some of them are very, um, you know, are genetically distinct.'

Dr. M:'I think that's the thing because the way the process works is actually different if you used, if you had a small number of cells, like three cells, then at early stages you could start with them kind of being, you know, like, you could control, you could change parameters of the process, and things like your membrane potential could be controlled. If you had, I don't know, maybe six, seven cells, you couldn't control that, you know, you would have a system that was so hard to tune. And if you had, you know, one million cells, like, that's insane. It's, it's, you know, so, I don't think the main difference is the number of cells, but there is the complexity, it's different. I think maybe what they're saying to me is how do we start with the complexity and how do we start, you know, with multiple kinds of neurons?'
Dr. B:'Is there a higher order cortex in humans, although there still remains a large degree of controversy.'
Dr. M:'I don't think people have a real concept of the purpose. In other words, what's their fundamental biological output?'
Dr. B:'I don't know, but as an output, that's what I am interested in.'
Dr. M:'Theoretical ideas about the brain are always hard to get in, because we're all interested in our own brains.'
Dr. B:(laughter) 'I'm working on the brain, I think of it as a circuit system.'

Dr. B:-but to understand the function of an entire circuit? Or like why we have those-like, oh my god, I-I read this book, this was incredible, about how, the theory from biology about how evolution of neurons works. They studied these small crustacean (laughter) neurons.'

Dr. M:'The brain is being formed, and the association areas – or the ganglia – have to be developed, and the developing brain is just building circuits. So, the development of this network of neurons that makes the brain an organ is being regulated. And, of course, there are also the mechanisms of the neuromodulatory projection neurons that release substances that enter into the brain. And then as the brain develops, it develops motor patterns that drive the motor neuron. Although the role of neuromodulators is not yet fully clarified, because, clearly, the brain is not behaving like muscle fibers when it moves and it is active at the same time that it is behaving. So clearly there are multiple purposes that might be served by these projections, either to excite and initiate other neurons, or to regulate the electrical properties of a neuron or a circuit, or to create a feedback that regulates the intrinsic properties of that particular neuron as it develops.'
Dr. B: 'Can you tell me what you have written about the function of a secondary soma?'

Dr. M: Well, again, you have heard that the secondary soma is not necessary to activate a neuron at all. This is a neuron that doesn't contribute to the output of the neuron at all, but merely processes sensory information.'

Dr. B:'So this is why we have the secondary soma, which is necessary for a neuron to fire, but not for a neuron to be a part of an association path. I disagree. The secondary soma is necessary for a neural syntax, a coding mechanism. It is essential for a neuron that can communicate to its primary axon. And this is why the secondary soma and not the primary soma is responsible for the primary neuronal goal and function of a neuron.'

Dr. M:'I believe that you are, again, missing the point entirely. We know it is necessary for a cell to spike in order to transmit information and be part of the association of other cells, but we also know that is not always enough. A cell needs to be part of a larger circuit where its cell can contribute to the goal of the circuit. At this point, we do not have information about how the sensory cortex behaves.'
Dr. M:'To connect the neurons with each other and with the motor cortex.'
Dr. B:'What mechanisms are put in place for this? In the language that you would like to employ for this I would like to ask what is the mechanism from my vantage point?'
Dr. B:'Oh and to produce synaptic connections between, like, different modulatory neurons and different motor neurons?'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'Is it fair to say that the brain can solve this problem in a matter of seconds? I mean the other problem is that it turns out to be a more complex problem, but the brain has to deal with it.
